abstract: A simple object-drawing task confirms a three-way association between object categorisation, viewpoint independence, and longer-term visual remembering. Young children (5- to 7-year-olds) drew a familiar object or a novel object, immediately after it had been hidden from view or on the following day. Both objects were shown from a full range of viewpoints or from just two viewpoints, from neither of which would either object normally be drawn after unrestricted viewing. When drawing from short-term memory after restricted viewing, both objects were most likely to be depicted from a seen viewpoint. When drawing from longer-term memory after restricted viewing, the novel object continued to be drawn from a seen viewpoint, but the mug was now most likely to be drawn from a preferred viewpoint from which it had not been seen. Naming the novel object with a novel count noun ("Look at this. This is a dax"), to signal that it belonged to an object category, resulted in it being drawn in the same way as the familiar object. The results concur with other evidence indicating that short-term and longer-term visual remembering are differentially associated with viewpoint-dependent representations of individual objects and viewpoint independent representations of object categories, respectively

Object Categorisation 2
Abstract
A simple object drawing task confirms a three-way association between object categorisation, 
viewpoint-independence, and longer-term visual remembering. Young children (5- to 7-year-
olds) drew a familiar object, or a novel object, immediately it had been hidden from view, or 
on the following day. Both objects were shown from a full range of viewpoints, or from just 
two viewpoints, from neither of which would either object normally be drawn after 
unrestricted viewing. When drawing from short-term memory after restricted viewing, both 
objects were most likely to be depicted from a seen viewpoint. When drawing from longer-
term memory after restricted viewing, the novel object continued to be drawn from a seen 
viewpoint, but the mug was now most likely to be drawn from a preferred viewpoint from 
which it had not been seen. Naming the novel object with a novel count noun (“Look at this. 
This is a dax”), to signal that it belonged to an object category, resulted in it being drawn in 
the same way as the familiar object. The results concur with other evidence indicating that 
short-term and longer-term visual remembering are differentially associated with viewpoint-
dependent representations of individual objects and viewpoint-independent representations of 
object categories, respectively.

Object Categorisation 3
Object Categorisation, Object Naming, and Viewpoint-Independence in Visual 
Remembering: Evidence From Young Childrens’ Drawings of a Novel Object
Evidence is accumulating to suggest that short-term and longer-term visual 
remembering can rely on representations that preserve contrasting information about objects. 
For example, compared to short-term remembering, longer-term remembering is more likely 
to reflect visual information about object categories than about specific objects (Avons & 
Phillips, 1987; Burgund & Marsolek, 2000; Marsolek, 1995), and information that specifies 
object shape categorically rather than with metric accuracy (Rosielle & Cooper, 2001). It is 
less likely to reflect either the specific viewpoint(s) from which objects were originally seen1
(Biederman & Cooper, 1991, 1992; Biederman & Gerhardstein, 1993; Cooper, 1994; Cooper 
& Schacter, 1992; Ellis, Allport, Humphreys, & Collis, 1989; Seamon & Delgado, 1999; 
Seamon, Ganor-Stern et al., 1997; Stankiewicz et al., 1998; Stankiewicz & Hummel, 2002), 
or the colours of objects (Brandimonte, Schooler, & Gabbino, 1997; Cooper, 1994; Hitch, 
Brandimonte, & Walker, 1995; Seamon et al., 1997; Walker et al., 1997).
These contrasting aspects of objects, that are differentially associated with short-term 
and longer-term remembering, might be preserved in two distinct types of visual 
representation. Candidate representations are images, such as those proposed by Tarr (e.g., 
Tarr, 1995), and structural descriptions, such as the geon structural descriptions (GSDs) 
proposed by Biederman (e.g., Biederman, 1995). Images are object-specific, preserve 
information about the object’s orientation in depth relative to the viewer, and are likely to 
capture all the visible features of an object (e.g., its surface colour). In contrast, GSDs 
represent object categories at an intermediate level of abstraction, and focus on the shape of 
category relevant object parts in their spatial configuration, to the exclusion of information 
about an object’s material properties (including colour). With shape being encoded

Object Categorisation 4
categorically, rather than with metric accuracy, GSDs are tolerant to the variation in shape 
among exemplars from a category. They are also largely insensitive to orientation in depth, 
and so can represent object categories in a way that is viewpoint-independent. Perhaps, 
therefore, it is because these two forms of representation are differentially associated with 
short-term and longer-term remembering, that information about contrasting aspects of 
objects has varying relevance depending on memory delay. The proposal is not that short-
term and longer-term remembering are exclusively dependent on different types of 
representation, but rather that, though both types of representation can support visual 
remembering in most situations, there is a tendency for short-term remembering to rely on 
image-like representations, and longer-term remembering to rely on GSD-like structural 
descriptions when these are available.  
If the various features of objects reflected in longer-term visual remembering are 
preserved in a single representation, then their impact on performance should be highly 
correlated. For example, when participants appear to rely on visual category representations 
in longer-term remembering, their performance should also confirm the viewpoint-
independence of these representations. Conversely, when participants are deprived of the 
opportunity to rely on category representations, longer-term remembering should reveal the 
same sensitivity to viewpoint that is observed in short-term remembering, because in both 
situations viewpoint-dependent object representations will mediate performance. 
The two experiments reported here were undertaken as part of a project examining 
intellectual realism in young children’s drawings (cf. Walker et al., 2006). As a source of 
information about the cognitive resources supporting drawing, young children offer the 
advantage that they are relatively unconstrained by culturally-determined drawing 
conventions, and their drawings are susceptible to a range of variables. The first experiment

Object Categorisation 5
examines the three-way association between object categorisation, viewpoint-independence, 
and longer-term remembering. Based on the understanding that naming a novel object with a 
novel count noun can establish a category representation for the object, the second 
experiment provides converging evidence for the role of object categorisation by examining 
the three-way association between object naming. viewpoint-independence, and longer-term 
remembering.
Experiment 1
Experiment 1 asks if the availability of a visual object category representation will 
increase the viewpoint-independence evident in drawings based on longer-term remembering. 
Young children completed a simple drawing task in which they drew either a novel object or 
a familiar object, under short-term or longer-term memory conditions. The novel object 
comprised a cube with a cone attached to the centre of one face. The familiar object was a 
drinking mug. Prior to drawing, the objects were presented for inspection, either from a full 
range of viewpoints, or from a single viewpoint from which the cone/handle pointed to the 
left from the child’s vantage point. This viewpoint was chosen because it is not one from 
which either object is normally drawn from memory after unrestricted viewing. Thus, 
drinking mugs are normally drawn from memory with their handle pointing to the drawer’s 
right. The novel object is normally drawn either with the cone pointing to the drawer’s right, 
or with the cone pointing upwards (Walker et al., 2006). After being presented for inspection, 
the objects were placed so that the cone/handle could not be seen (i.e., with the cone/handle 
pointing directly away from the child). Neither object was named by the experimenter during 
the experiment.
Viewpoint-dependent object representations preserve information about objects only 
in relation to the viewpoints from which they have been seen. Drawings based on these

Object Categorisation 6
representations should, therefore, be most likely to depict an object from a viewpoint from 
which it has been seen. Because geon-like structural descriptions of object categories are 
largely invariant to viewpoint, drawings based on these need not be constrained by viewpoint 
in this way, allowing the drawer to depict an object from a viewpoint from which it has not 
been seen. Given the presumed viewpoint-invariance of visual category representations, it 
was predicted that when the objects were seen from just the two viewpoints used in the 
restricted viewing conditions, the presence of an established category representation for the 
mug would increase the likelihood of it being depicted from a different (unseen) viewpoint. 
In addition, given the presumed association between category representations and longer-
term remembering, it was predicted that the effect of object familiarity would only be 
observed with longer-term remembering. Object familiarity was not expected to have an 
effect when the objects were seen from a full range of viewpoints prior to drawing, or when 
they were drawn from short-term memory. Put differently, memory delay2 was expected to 
impact on drawing only when the familiar object was presented from a restricted set of 
viewpoints. 
Method
Participants
One hundred and sixty 5- to 7-year-olds participated in Experiment 1 (mean age =  6 
years 4 months; age range = 5 years 0 months to 7 years 11 months).  
Materials
The familiar object was a plain white cylindrical mug, 12 cm high, with a base radius 
of 6 cm. The novel object was made from wood, and comprised a 12 cm cube with a cone 
attached to the centre of one face. The cone had a base radius of 3 cm, and a height of 8 cm.

This object was smoothed and painted with red gloss paint. Each child was provided with a

Design
An independent-groups design was created by crossing three factors, each with two 
levels. The factors were Object Familiarity (novel object versus mug), Viewing Condition 
(restricted viewing versus unrestricted viewing), and Memory Delay (short-term 
remembering versus longer-term remembering). An equal number of participants (n = 20) 
were assigned randomly to each of the eight groups, with the constraint that the groups were 
matched for age and gender. 
Procedure
All the children were tested individually in a quiet section of their classroom, with a 
table separating them from the experimenter. The same procedure was used regardless of the 
familiarity of the object to be drawn, and at no point did the experimenter provide a name for 
either object. For every child, the experimenter started by removing a plain, up-turned 
cardboard box, positioned in the centre of the table, to reveal the object to be drawn. The 
object was positioned with its attached part (i.e., the cone or handle) pointing to the left from 
the child’s vantage point. In the restricted viewing condition, the experimenter picked up the 
object and held it in front of the child without changing its orientation. In the unrestricted 
viewing condition, the experimenter picked up the object and proceeded to rotate it, following 
a carefully rehearsed routine, so that the child was exposed equally to each major facet of the 
object. While presenting each object to the child, the experimenter said “Look at this object.” 
After presenting the object for 20 s, the experimenter replaced it on the table with the 
cone/handle now hidden from view, that is, with the cone/handle pointing away from the 
child. The experimenter then primed the child for the drawing task. In the short-term

children in the short-term remembering condition also to return the following day to produce 
a second drawing of the object. After producing their first drawing, the experimenter told 
them “Tomorrow, I want you to draw this object again.” Thereafter, they were treated in the 
same way as children in the long-term remembering condition.

Discussion
When young children drew an object from memory, the extent to which their 
depictions were constrained by the viewpoints from which the object had been seen was 
influenced by the object’s familiarity, and by whether the object was being drawn from short-
term or longer-term memory. Specifically, with the shift from short-term to longer-term 
remembering, the children became more inclined to depict a familiar object from a (normally 
preferred) viewpoint from which it had not been seen. The same trend was absent in their 
drawings of a novel object. This three-way association between object familiarity, viewpoint-
independence, and memory delay, was predicted on the basis that distinct types of visual 
object representation are differentially associated with short-term and longer-term 
remembering (cf. Introduction). To reiterate, though viewpoint-dependent, image-like 
representations of objects, and viewpoint-independent, GSD-like structural descriptions of 
object categories, are normally available to support both short-term and longer-term 
remembering, there is a tendency for people to utilise the former in short-term remembering 
and the latter in longer-term remembering. Because GSD-like category representations were 
available only for the mug, only for this object could the viewpoint-independence of these 
representations remove the constraints associated with restricted viewing when the children 
drew from long-term memory. When the children either drew from short-term memory or

Experiment 2
Bozeat et al. (2003), in a study of semantic dementia, have shown that with memory 
delay drawings can become progressively more dependent on generic visual knowledge, even 
when the instruction is to draw the particular object the experimenter had shown them. With 
this in mind, some uncertainty must remain concerning the extent to which depictions of the 
mug from an unseen viewpoint after restricted viewing in the present study were drawings of 
a generic mug, rather than drawings of the particular mug shown to them by the 
experimenter. Uncertainty remains because there was nothing distinctive about the mug that, 
if reproduced in the drawing, would have confirmed that it was that specific mug that was 
being drawn. In principle, such uncertainty can be removed by using novel objects as 
experimental stimuli, especially if a simple and effective way can be found to induce 
participants to establish a category representation for a novel object on the basis of a single 
encounter.
Rosch et al. (1976) and Hoffman, Denis, and Ziessler (1983) have demonstrated that 
common object names are linked most directly to visual representations of object categories 
at an intermediate level of abstraction (i.e., at the basic-level). The impact of object naming 
on the creation of category representations confirms this privileged link. Thus, naming a 
novel object with a novel count noun induces infants and young children to establish a shape-
based category representation for the object (Baldwin, 1989; Hall, 1993; Hall & Moore, 
1997; Hall, Quantz, & Persoage, 2000; Hall & Waxman, 1993; Landau, 1994; Landau, 
Smith, & Jones, 1988; 1992; Smith, Jones, & Landau, 1992; Waxman, 1999; Waxman &

Discussion
Young children engaged in the object drawing task were induced to treat the novel 
object in the same way that children in Experiment 1 had treated the mug. Thus, when the 
object was named with a novel count noun as it was being inspected prior to drawing, their 
drawings from longer-term memory became independent of the viewpoints from which the 
object had been seen. Their drawings from short-term memory were not influenced by object 
naming.
Because naming a novel object with a novel count noun is known to induce children 
to establish a category representation for the object (cf. above), this new result helps to 
confirm that it was the availability of a visual category representation that allowed the 
children in Experiment 1 to draw the mug from longer-term memory in a way that was 
independent of the particular viewpoints from which it had been seen. This result also

General Discussion
The results from the present experiments are consistent with the proposal that distinct 
types of visual object representation are differentially associated with short-term and longer-
term remembering. Specifically, though viewpoint-dependent object representations and 
viewpoint-independent structural descriptions of object categories can both support short-
term and longer-term remembering, the former representations tend to be most influential in 
short-term remembering, the latter in longer-term remembering. Given the relative 
insensitivity of GSD-like structural descriptions of object categories to orientation in depth, 
and their privileged links with object (category) names, it is understandable that both object 
familiarity and object naming induced children to depict objects in ways that were not 
constrained by the particular viewpoints from which the objects had been seen. The fact that 
this was observed only with longer-term remembering, and not with short-term remembering, 
confirms the three-way association between object categorisation, viewpoint-independence, 
and longer-term remembering.
Children in the restricted viewing condition were induced to depict the objects from a 
viewpoint from which the objects had not been seen, even though they had been requested to 
depict them from the final viewpoint from which they had been seen (i.e., with the 
handle/cone hidden from view). It could be argued, therefore, that object familiarity and 
object naming both impaired performance. 
The potentially detrimental effects of object familiarity and object naming on visual 
remembering, and the restriction of these effects to longer-term remembering, have also been 
revealed in studies of visual image combination (cf. Brandimonte, Hitch, & Bishop, 1992;

asked to combine a visual image of a recently presented line drawing with an image of a 
current line drawing. They were then to discover the identity of the object resulting from this 
combination. The nature of the to-be-combined drawings was such that identification of the

metrically accurate. In some situations, the recently presented visual stimulus was either still 
available in short-term memory (because no other item had been presented in the interim), or 
was available only in longer-term memory (because other task-relevant items had been 
presented in the interim). In addition, it was arranged that when the memory item depicted a 
familiar object, it was either named or unnamed at presentation. In agreement with the results 
of the present study, participants were less able to complete the image combination task if the 
object depicted in the first drawing was named at presentation. Moreover, this detrimental 
effect of naming was observed only with longer-term remembering, and not with short-term 
remembering. Walker et al. (1997) proposed that performance was impaired by object 
naming because this induced participants to increase their reliance on a visual representation 
of the category to which the object belonged, with the effect that the shape of the object 
became less accurately described (i.e., there was a shift towards shape being described 
categorically rather than with metric accuracy). Finally, additional support for the current 
proposal emerged with the observation that performance in the image combination task was 
insensitive to the colour congruity of the to-be-combined stimuli, but only when longer-term 
remembering was being assessed and the first of the two figures had been named (Hitch, 
Brandimonte, & Walker, 1995; Walker et al., 1997). With short-term remembering, image 
combination was impaired when the two figures to be combined appeared in different colours

memory (see, for example, Cooper, 1994, and Srinivas, 1996). For example, though long-
term priming in object naming and object decision tasks has been shown to involve visual 
representations that do not preserve information about viewpoint and object colour, explicit 
recognition memory for the same stimuli has been shown to involve visual representations 
preserving information about these two features (Biederman & Cooper, 1991, 1992; Cooper, 
1994; Cooper & Schacter, 1992; Seamon & Delgado, 1999; Seamon, Ganor-Stern et al., 
1997; Srinivas, 1996). Clearly, therefore, a full account of the representational basis of visual 
remembering will need to acknowledge the distinction between implicit and explicit tests of 
memory. Nevertheless, the results reported here confirm that an explicit test of memory  (i.e., 
the present object drawing task) can reveal the varying contributions of different types of 
visual representation. Although the image combination task also is a test of explicit memory 
that can do this, the object drawing task has the advantage that there are no restrictions on the 
stimuli that can be utilised.

Footnote
1
 The terms viewpoint-dependent and viewpoint-independent are intended to refer to the 
extent to which the representation of an object is restricted to the viewpoint(s) from which the 
object has been seen. It is not intended to refer to the extent to which an object might be 
represented from a specific viewpoint (e.g., a canonical view), which could or could not be a 
viewpoint from which the object has been seen.
2
 Use of the term ‘memory delay’ is not intended to imply that the critical factor 
distinguishing short-term and longer-term remembering is the passage of time. Likely to be 
important is the interposition of other visual events requiring cognitive resources (e.g., 
attention), whether these events are external in origin (e.g., the presentation of another visual 
object), or internal in origin (e.g., the generation of a visual image from long-term 
knowledge).
